awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Active assignment of quantifier scope guides language processing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Language processing often appears to be effortless as humans rapidly decode linguistic signals to form meaningful representations of what they have just heard or read. While much of what has been observed in human language processing is well predicted by linguistic theory, some grammatically illicit sentences are perceived as acceptable. These linguistic illusions, where observed behavior does not align neatly with predictions of well-established grammatical theories, provide opportunities to observe differences between the structure of language and how language is processed. This doctoral dissertation project addresses one of these illusions, the negative polarity item illusion, and develops a new framework in which the illusion follows as a consequence of independent principles for processing quantification and scope. Developing frameworks for the processes that drive these linguistic illusions is critical for both our grammatical theories and theories of language related behavior. Beyond the benefits to linguistic and language processing research, these models also provide critical theoretical scaffolding for work in domains such as human computer interaction and neurolinguistics.

This project uses eye-tracking while reading along with other online and offline measures to observe the processing of various kinds of sentences. These include sentences which are related to the negative polarity item illusion and are designed to isolate how different factors such as polarity valence and the syntactic environment contribute to the observed illusion effect. Additional sentences investigated are designed to examine how scope is computed in online processing, a critical but understudied factor in the negative polarity item illusion. Based on existing research and the newly acquired data, the primary goal of the project is the development of a new model for the processing of scope and quantification called reckless scope processing, which recasts a problematic illusion as an expected consequence of a necessary language processing procedure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Humans process language as it unfolds quickly and with minimal conscious effort. As language is rule-based and structured, many of the strategies humans use to understand language are relatively easily predicted from these underlying rules. However, there are some cases where the language behaviors we observe do not align with predictions based on these linguistic rules. These cases are often called linguistic illusions. By studying these illusions, we can observe the properties of the language processing system that are not direct implementations linguistic rules. This doctoral dissertation project focused on polarity illusions and developed a new account in which polarity illusions follow as a consequence of a language processing procedure related to quantification and scope. This award facilitated the creation of a successful dissertation and several additional publications and research presentations on topics related to the dissertation.

The work conducted as part of this award has contributed substantially to the empirical and theoretical development of the areas of language processing and syntax. Empirically this work resulted in significant expansion of our understanding in 4 areas of sentence processing. First, this project investigated the distribution of the negative polarity item illusion testing several potential illusion triggers and uncovered that the illusion only takes place in the presence of quantified negation. Second, this work tested the possibility that there is a counterpart of the negative polarity item illusion for positive polarity items. In studies employing various language processing methodologies we show that there is an illusion for positive polarity items, the illusion has a reversed cost profile of the negative polarity item illusion, and that the occurrence of the positive polarity item illusion is also restricted sentences to quantifier negation. Third, this project tested polarity illusions outside of the context of the relative clause, finding that different sentential configurations can modulate the illusions presence and the direction of the effect. Fourth and finally, this project also investigated the online processing of sentences with ellipsis and quantification, providing novel insight into when scope is evaluated online. Taken together, the project meaningfully expanded our empirical coverage in the processing of polarity and scope.

This project also had several theoretical contributions. The primary contribution is the development of the active scope processing framework for the resolution of scope relations online. This new paradigm makes predictions for language processing behaviors related to scope and quantification that are meaningfully different than existing alternatives. Importantly these predictions align with the empirical observations reported in the paragraph above. A secondary contribution is the new approach to polarity illusions which collapses the negative polarity item and positive polarity item illusions into a single class of polarity illusion, which simply produce effects of the opposite direction. This recategorization more accurately captures the source of the illusion effects and invites further exploration with the goal of identifying illusion cases which can result in both processing facilitation and penalties. Taken together, the empirical and theoretical contributions of this project open the door for more targeted research on the areas of polarity and scope in language processing.

This work also produced several broader benefits. First the project supported an undergraduate researcher through an REU experience,  providing hands on training and experience in formal and experimental linguistics. This work also greatly expanded our understanding of the processing of polarity, an area which remains particularly important in the realm of computational linguistics. As polarity phenomena continue be challenging for many large language models to replicate, the expansion of the empirical landscape of polarity phenomena produced during this project supplies critical data for the refinement of this aspect of various computational approaches to language. These empirical contributions are likewise potentially important to neurolinguistics for their potential to identify issues which may appear uniquely in linguistic representational or language processing.
